square.$description: Square — equal width and height for perfectly balanced layouts.

landscape.$description: Landscape — slightly wider than tall, common for photos and videos.

portrait.$description: Portrait — taller than wide, ideal for mobile and print formats.

wide.$description: Wide — standard for modern screens, videos, and presentations.

ultrawide.$description: Ultra wide — cinematic aspect for immersive content.

golden.$description: Golden ratio — classic proportion used for balanced, aesthetic designs.

sm.$description: Small blur — subtle softening for fine UI elements.

md.$description: Medium blur — balanced softness for shadows or backgrounds.

lg.$description: Large blur — noticeable softness for emphasis or layering.

xl.$description: Extra large blur — strong softness for overlays or glass effects.

2xl.$description: Double extra large blur — deep background separation.

3xl.$description: Triple extra large blur — heavy atmospheric blur for dramatic depth.

4xl.$description: Quadruple extra large blur — extreme softness for immersive visual effects.

xs.$description: Extra small — ultra-thin hairline borders for subtle dividers.

sm.$description: Small — standard thin border for UI elements and outlines.

md.$description: Medium — noticeable border for emphasis or strong separation.

lg.$description: Large — bold border for cards, panels, or high-contrast elements.

xl.$description: Extra large — very thick border for decorative or standout designs.

button.$description: Mouse cursor while hovering on a button

checkbox.$description: Mouse cursor while hovering on a checkbox

disabled.$description: Mouse cursor while hovering on disbaled items

menuitem.$description: Mouse cursor while hovering on a menu item

option.$description: Mouse cursor while hovering on a select option

radio.$description: Mouse cursor while hovering on a radio button

slider.$description: Mouse cursor while hovering on a slider

switch.$description: Mouse cursor while hovering on a switch toggle

fastest.$description: Fastest speed for transitions and animations

faster.$description: Faster speed for transitions and animations

fast.$description: Fast speed for transitions and animations

moderate.$description: Moderate (default) speed for transitions and animations

slow.$description: Slow speed for transitions and animations

slower.$description: Slower speed for transitions and animations

slowest.$description: Slowest speed for transitions and animations

md.$description: Medium (default) font size. On web this usually equals to 16px, or 1rem

body.$value: Inter, -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, "Segoe UI", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif, "Apple Color Emoji", "Segoe UI Emoji", "Segoe UI Symbol"
body.$description: Default font family for body text

1.$description: 1 unit — minimal spacing for icons, tight component gaps.

2.$description: 2 units — small spacing for compact layouts or small padding.

3.$description: 3 units — in-between spacing for small elements, tighter grouping.

4.$description: 4 units — base spacing; standard gap between related elements.

5.$description: 5 units — medium spacing for comfortable separation in content.

6.$description: 6 units — larger padding for cards, sections, and container edges.

7.$description: 7 units — generous spacing for clear separation of grouped content.

9.$description: 9 units — large gap for distinct visual separation.

10.$description: 10 units — ideal for whitespace in clean, spacious layouts.

11.$description: 11 units — specific use for tall UI elements or large button padding.

12.$description: 12 units — extra large spacing for major section separation.

14.$description: 14 units — large whitespace for prominent layout breaks.

16.$description: 16 units — significant gap for distinct content areas.

20.$description: 20 units — very large spacing, used sparingly for emphasis.

24.$description: 24 units — substantial whitespace for hero sections or major dividers.

28.$description: 28 units — very wide spacing for oversized layouts or banners.

32.$description: 32 units — extra-wide spacing for full-screen layout breaks.

36.$description: 36 units — large whitespace for immersive content separation.

40.$description: 40 units — maximum spacing for distinct visual segmentation.

44.$description: 44 units — ultra-large spacing for special layout cases.

48.$description: 48 units — expansive gap for hero content or visual breathing space.

52.$description: 52 units — oversized spacing for full-width banners or sections.

56.$description: 56 units — extreme whitespace for premium layouts.

60.$description: 60 units — extreme spacing, rarely used except for very large displays.

64.$description: 64 units — massive gap for bold visual separation.

72.$description: 72 units — super large spacing for cinematic layouts.

80.$description: 80 units — largest standard spacing token, for standout layout divisions.

96.$description: 96 units — exceptional spacing for rare, impactful design moments.

half.$description: Half unit — smallest spacing for fine adjustments, hairline gaps.

hide.$description: Used to visually hide elements beneath the base layer—commonly for offscreen or visually hidden UI

base.$description: The default stacking context for basic content—acts as the baseline

docked.$description: For fixed-position UI elements (like toolbars or docked panels) that should sit above base content but below overlays; docked elements shouldn’t interfere with content layering

dropdown.$description: Used for dropdown menus, ensuring they sit above static content

sticky.$description: For elements that stick (e.g., headers or navigation bars) that should overlay dropdowns

banner.$description: For persistent banners or notifications that overlap sticky headers

overlay.$description: Used for semi-transparent overlays behind dialogs or modals

modal.$description: Assigned to modal dialogs themselves, placing them above overlays

popover.$description: For popover components—tooltips, floating info boxes—that need to appear above modals

skipNav.$description: Typically used for skip navigation links (e.g., "skip to content")—they should be on top of all else for accessibility

toast.$description: For toast notifications, which should overlay nearly everything except tooltips

tooltip.$description: For tooltips, which sit above even modals and toasts in context

max.$description: A programmatic max value (2³¹−1)—used when you want an element to appear above absolutely everything

50.$description: Lightest gray — subtle neutral tint for backgrounds and minimal emphasis.

100.$description: Very light gray — soft neutral for hover states and gentle separation.

150.$description: Light gray — gentle tone for borders and disabled element backgrounds.

200.$description: Soft gray — calm neutral for secondary backgrounds and subtle dividers.

250.$description: Medium-light gray — balanced neutral for placeholder text and quiet elements.

300.$description: Moderate gray — reliable neutral for secondary text and supportive elements.

350.$description: Medium gray — versatile neutral for icons and moderate emphasis text.

400.$description: Balanced gray — clear neutral for labels and informational text.

450.$description: Strong gray — noticeable neutral for secondary headings and emphasis.

500.$description: Core gray — primary neutral for body text and standard UI elements.

550.$description: Deep gray — substantial neutral for important text and strong hierarchy.

600.$description: Darker gray — prominent neutral for headings and emphasized content.

650.$description: Strong dark gray — bold neutral for high-contrast text and key elements.

700.$description: Dark gray — serious neutral for navigation and structural elements.

750.$description: Very dark gray — deep neutral for contrast and sophisticated backgrounds.

800.$description: Deep charcoal — rich neutral for high-contrast interfaces and premium feel.

850.$description: Darker charcoal — strong neutral for dramatic backgrounds and bold statements.

900.$description: Very dark charcoal — intense neutral for maximum contrast and depth.

950.$description: Darkest gray — near-black neutral for ultimate contrast and elegant darkness.

50.$description: Lightest blue — soft sky tint for subtle backgrounds and gentle highlights.

100.$description: Very light blue — delicate shade for hover states and secondary backgrounds.

150.$description: Light blue — gentle tone for disabled states and subtle borders.

200.$description: Soft blue — calm shade for secondary UI elements and quiet accents.

250.$description: Medium-light blue — balanced tone for informational elements and gentle emphasis.

300.$description: Moderate blue — reliable shade for secondary buttons and supportive elements.

350.$description: Medium blue — versatile tone for interactive elements and moderate emphasis.

400.$description: Bright blue — vibrant shade for links, active states, and clear call-to-actions.

450.$description: Strong blue — bold tone for primary buttons and important interactive elements.

500.$description: Primary blue — core brand color for main actions and key UI components.

550.$description: Deep blue — rich tone for pressed states and strong visual hierarchy.

600.$description: Darker blue — substantial shade for focus states and emphasized elements.

650.$description: Strong dark blue — bold tone for headers and important text elements.

700.$description: Dark blue — serious shade for navigation and structural elements.

750.$description: Very dark blue — deep tone for contrast and sophisticated backgrounds.

800.$description: Deep navy — rich shade for high-contrast text and premium elements.

850.$description: Darker navy — strong tone for dramatic backgrounds and bold statements.

900.$description: Very dark navy — intense shade for maximum contrast and depth.

950.$description: Darkest blue — midnight tone for dramatic depth and ultimate contrast.
